publishedTexts.name: ofedchen
publishedTexts.prompt: Free writing
publishedTexts.text:
Elliot had spent twenty years tending the lighthouse on Blackthorn Isle. The job was lonely, but he liked it that way. Each night, the beam swept across the restless sea, guiding ships safely to shore.

One stormy evening, as waves crashed against the rocks, Elliot heard something unusual—a faint knock at the heavy wooden door. No one ever came here. Heart pounding, he unlatched it. A young woman stood there, drenched, her dark hair clinging to her face.

“You have to hide me,” she gasped.

Without a word, Elliot stepped aside. He gave her dry clothes, a warm seat by the fire, and a cup of tea. Through the window, he saw a lantern bobbing along the shore—someone searching.

“Who are you running from?” he asked.

She hesitated, then whispered, “A man who never lets go of what he owns.”

Elliot understood. He had once run, too.

He stood, doused the lighthouse flame, and plunged the island into darkness. Out at sea, a ship’s horn blared—a warning lost to the storm. The girl watched him in shock.

“No light, no way to find you,” he said.

The wind howled outside, but inside, it was safe.

publishedTexts.name: kajsaduvet
publishedTexts.prompt: Describe a day in the life of someone living in a futuristic city where robots and humans coexist.
publishedTexts.text:
Morning: AI-Optimized Wake-Up & Commute
As the sun rises, an AI-powered home assistant gently wakes Alex with a personalized sunrise simulation and soothing music. The smart bed adjusts automatically, helping with posture and circulation. In the kitchen, a robotic chef prepares a nutrient-optimized breakfast tailored to Alex’s biometric readings from the night before.  

A self-driving pod waits outside, summoned via thought-controlled interface. The city's AI traffic system ensures a seamless, congestion-free ride. Drones whiz above, delivering packages, while humanoid robots perform maintenance on towering green skyscrapers.  

Workday: Humans & AI Collaboration
Alex works in a creative industry, where AI handles data processing while humans focus on innovation. In an open-concept office, robotic assistants provide research summaries and organize tasks. Some colleagues work remotely via holographic projections, attending meetings in real-time with fully interactive avatars.  

Breaks are enhanced by smart relaxation pods that provide meditation, muscle therapy, and even immersive virtual vacations. Co-bots (collaborative robots) assist in brainstorming sessions, offering insights based on massive datasets.  

Afternoon: Leisure in a High-Tech Oasis
During lunch, Alex visits a floating park, a serene green space suspended above the city by anti-gravity tech. AI gardeners maintain exotic plant life, and delivery drones serve personalized meals based on dietary history. Robots and humans coexist seamlessly—some relaxing, others jogging with robotic fitness companions.  

Afterward, Alex stops at a mind-interface café, where thoughts control the menu, and robotic baristas prepare hyper-personalized beverages. Payment is contactless—biometric scans ensure instant transactions.  

Evening: Entertainment & Socializing
After work, Alex heads to a mixed-reality entertainment hub, where friends (both local and virtual) meet in a fully immersive, interactive world. AI-powered musicians perform, adapting to audience preferences in real-time. Meanwhile, robots handle security and logistics, ensuring a smooth experience.  

Later, a short hyperloop ride takes Alex home. The smart home has adjusted lighting and temperature to optimal levels. Before bed, a robotic masseuse provides relaxation therapy, and an AI-generated bedtime story plays through spatial audio, customizing itself to Alex’s mood.  

As the city hums with a quiet, efficient rhythm, Alex drifts off, knowing that tomorrow will bring even more seamless innovation in this harmonious world where humans and robots thrive together.

publishedTexts.name: moremorin
publishedTexts.prompt: Tell the tale of a mysterious traveler who grants wishes—but at a cost.
publishedTexts.text:
The stranger arrived at dusk, cloaked in a tattered robe that shimmered like the night sky. He carried no bags, no money—only a single silver ring, which he twisted absentmindedly on his finger as he walked.  

He never knocked, never announced himself. He simply appeared when someone needed him most.  

On this night, he entered the dimly lit tavern of Black Hollow, where the desperate and the broken nursed their misfortunes. Whispers spread as he settled into a shadowed corner. One by one, the curious approached him, drawn by the strange aura he exuded—an invisible force, both alluring and ominous.  

A man with hollow eyes and trembling hands sat before him first. "I wish for wealth," he muttered. "Enough to never suffer again."  

The traveler studied him, then nodded. "Granted," he said, voice smooth as silk. He reached across the table and tapped the man’s palm with a single finger. "But all debts must be paid."  

The man left that night to find his home miraculously filled with gold. But the next morning, his family had vanished—taken as payment by forces unseen.  

The second was a woman, bitter with age, longing for lost beauty. "Make me young again," she begged.  

Again, the traveler nodded. "Granted."  

By dawn, her youth had returned—but so had the pain of forgotten mistakes. Her mind remained old, haunted by memories she could not escape.  

The final soul to approach was a boy, no older than ten, his clothes threadbare, his eyes filled with silent sorrow. "I just want my mother back," he whispered.  

For the first time, the traveler hesitated. His fingers hovered over the silver ring.  

"A wish is a binding thing," he warned. "Are you willing to pay the cost?"  

The boy nodded.  

The traveler sighed, then touched the boy’s forehead.  

The next morning, the mother returned—whole, breathing, alive. The town rejoiced. But the boy was nowhere to be found.  

And the traveler? He had vanished before dawn, the silver ring now missing from his finger. Somewhere, in another town, a new one had taken its place.  

Waiting for the next desperate soul.

publishedTexts.name: rasmus
publishedTexts.prompt: Free writing
publishedTexts.text:
David sat in his car, engine idling, watching the reflection of a man he barely recognized. The lines on his face weren’t there yesterday. Or maybe they were, and he had only just begun to see them.  

Forty-five. The number sat heavy on his chest, heavier than the mortgage, heavier than the emails left unanswered. He used to laugh at the idea of a midlife crisis—sports cars, affairs, reckless abandon—but now, he understood. It wasn’t about rebellion. It was about vanishing.  

Somewhere between the late-night meetings and the early morning alarms, he had faded. His dreams, once sharp and neon-bright, had dulled to the beige of office walls.  

A notification blinked on his phone: Anniversary Dinner – 7 PM.

He was supposed to pick up flowers. Instead, he drove past the florist and kept going.  

Miles blurred. He passed places he hadn't seen in years—the old bar where he and his friends planned to change the world, the bookstore where he first met his wife, the bridge where he once stood, convinced that the city lights were stars within reach.  

He pulled over and stepped out. The air was colder than he expected. A group of teenagers sat on a bench, laughing, the sound weightless.  

David closed his eyes. What had he been chasing? Youth? Freedom? A version of himself that had long since packed up and left?  

He exhaled and checked his watch. 6:47 PM.

His hands gripped the wheel as he turned the car around, retracing his path back home.  

Maybe the crisis wasn’t about running.  

Maybe it was about remembering.

publishedTexts.name: ofedchen
publishedTexts.prompt: Imagine a world where humans can live underwater—how does society function?
publishedTexts.text: In the underwater cities of Ocealis, towering bio-domes of reinforced coral and glass house millions, while glowing kelp farms provide oxygen and food. Transportation relies on current-driven pods and personal propulsion suits, weaving through bioluminescent highways like schools of fish. Currency is based on energy credits, harnessed from deep-sea thermal vents and traded for necessities like desalinated water and synthetic materials. Crime is rare but policed by sonar-tracking enforcers, ensuring no one vanishes into the abyss without a trace. Yet, despite their oceanic paradise, many still dream of the surface—a forgotten world now lost beneath the waves.

publishedTexts.name: rhz1994
publishedTexts.prompt: Write about an inventor who creates a machine that can read minds.
publishedTexts.text:
In a dim and cluttered workshop, nestled between the grimy chimneys of a soot-stained London alley, there laboured a man of peculiar and solitary genius. Professor Algernon Babcock was his name, a gentleman of indeterminate years, his figure bent with the weight of ceaseless thought, his countenance drawn with the privations of one who preferred discovery to sustenance, contemplation to repose.

His invention—oh, but what a thing it was! A dreadful and marvellous contraption, its brass and copper coils glistening faintly in the gaslight, its delicate wires trembling with untapped potential. It was, he assured himself in the lonely hours of the night, the pinnacle of human intellect: a machine that could read the thoughts of men. The Mind’s Lantern, he called it, for did it not cast light upon the darkest chambers of the soul?

Yet, what a dreadful illumination it proved to be. For when at last the machine was complete—when its clicking gears and whispering valves summoned forth the silent voices of the mind—Professor Babcock was met not with the triumph he had long imagined, but with a terror too great for words. The thoughts of men were not noble, nor wise, nor filled with the purity he had once ascribed to them in his youth. Instead, they surged forth in a cacophony of greed, malice, envy, and deceit. The genteel merchant whose hand he shook harboured schemes of ruthless avarice; the mild-mannered widow who passed him in the street despised him with unspoken venom; even the newsboy, the ragged child with his cheery cry, cursed his existence with silent resentment.

Day by day, his heart withered under the weight of this terrible knowledge. He could not unhear the whispered betrayals, nor forget the venom that lay behind the brightest of smiles. And so, in the dead of night, with trembling hands and a mind burdened beyond endurance, he took up a hammer and shattered his creation into a thousand irreparable pieces. The Mind’s Lantern flickered, sputtered, and was gone.

And thus, Professor Algernon Babcock learned the most profound truth of all—that ignorance, indeed, is the only bliss afforded to man.

publishedTexts.name: rasmus
publishedTexts.prompt: Imagine a town where every citizen has a magical ability—but one person has none.
publishedTexts.text: In the town of Eldermere, every citizen is born with a unique magical gift, from summoning fire to speaking with spirits. But when Callen arrives as the first person without a single spark of magic, he begins to unravel a secret the town has desperately tried to keep buried—one that explains why his existence should be impossible.

publishedTexts.name: kajsaduvet
publishedTexts.prompt: Imagine a secret society that protects humanity from supernatural threats.
publishedTexts.text: The Veilkeepers operate in the shadows, erasing all traces of monsters, curses, and ancient evils before the world even knows they existed. To humanity, they are myths—but to the horrors lurking beyond reality, they are the last line of defense.

publishedTexts.text: I wonder if there are people whose superpower is to predict others superpowers!

publishedTexts.name: ofedchen
publishedTexts.prompt: Write about a person who wakes up to find they are the last human on Earth.
publishedTexts.text: The world was silent. Elin sat up in bed, rubbing her eyes. Something felt… wrong. No hum of traffic. No distant voices. Just an eerie, absolute stillness. She grabbed her phone. No signal. She checked the news. Error: No Connection. Heart pounding, she stepped outside. The street was empty. Cars sat abandoned at odd angles. A bicycle lay on its side, its wheels still. She called out. “Hello?” No answer. She ran to her neighbor’s house, pounded on the door. No response. Every house she checked was the same—doors unlocked, food still warm on tables, beds unmade. It was as if everyone had vanished in an instant. By noon, she was downtown, standing in the middle of the empty city. No birds. No wind. Just her own ragged breathing. She screamed. The sound echoed off buildings, but no one came. And then, just as the silence threatened to crush her, a screen flickered to life on a nearby billboard. A deep, mechanical voice spoke: “EXPERIMENT SUCCESSFUL. SUBJECT REMAINS. INITIATING PHASE TWO.” Elin took a step back, her pulse roaring in her ears. Somewhere behind her, a streetlight flickered. And then—footsteps. She wasn’t alone after all.

publishedTexts.name: kajsaduvet
publishedTexts.prompt: Write a story where someone receives a letter from their future self.
publishedTexts.text:
Ethan slumped into his chair after another exhausting day at work. As he tossed his keys on the table, his eyes landed on an envelope sitting neatly in the middle of his desk. No stamp. No return address. Just his name, written in his own handwriting.

His pulse quickened. Hands trembling, he tore it open.

"Ethan," the letter began. "I know you think this is a joke, but it’s not. I am you, ten years from now. And I need you to listen carefully."

Ethan’s breath hitched. He scanned the letter, his future self warning him not to take the job offer he was expecting next week. "It will seem like your dream job, but it will lead you somewhere dark. Say no. Trust me."

His mind raced. He hadn’t even told anyone about the offer yet. Was this an elaborate prank? He checked the paper—aged, slightly yellowed at the edges, as if it had really been sitting somewhere for a decade.

At the bottom of the letter was one final line:

"If you don’t believe me, wait for the blue car tomorrow at 3:17 PM. Then decide."

Ethan barely slept. The next afternoon, he sat by the window, eyes locked on the street. At exactly 3:17, a blue car screeched around the corner, running a red light before slamming into a lamppost.

His heart pounded. The letter was real.

And now, he had a choice to make.

publishedTexts.name: hampus
publishedTexts.prompt: Write a journal entry from someone living in a world where emotions can be programmed.
publishedTexts.text:
Journal Entry – March 10, 2047

I updated my emotions this morning. I decided on Optimized Productivity Mode—a blend of mild satisfaction, focus, and just enough ambition to push through deadlines without anxiety. It’s working well so far, though I caught myself missing the unpredictability of unregulated feelings.

At lunch, I ran into Aiden. He’s been experimenting with Raw Authenticity, which sounds terrifying. No filters, no suppressors—just pure, unchecked emotion. He said it makes him feel real. I told him I’d rather not risk sudden sadness or heartbreak over something trivial, but he laughed and said, “What’s the point of living if you don’t feel it all?”

It stuck with me.

Tonight, I switched to Nostalgic Warmth, a soft, golden emotion with hints of childhood memories. It makes everything feel safe, like a fading sunset. But something inside me wonders: are these emotions truly mine if I can edit them so easily? If I can remove sadness with a swipe, does happiness mean anything?

Maybe I’ll try Raw Authenticity tomorrow. Just for an hour. Maybe.
